abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Structural
            Adjustment Credit Project for Guinea was marginally
            unsatisfactory. The project achieved a few of its
            objectives, institutional development was negligible,
            sustainability is uncertain, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was marginally satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, SACs can be
            powerful instruments for supporting policy reforms. Second,
            the reforms supported must be properly sequenced and must be
            achievable within the time frame of the program. Third, the
            development of the reform program should be based on solid
            economic and sector work to, among other things, help define
            tranche release conditions in terms of outcomes rather than
            in terms of promulgation of legal measures. Finally, by
            offering alternative sources of quick disbursements,
            concurrent adjustment operations can seriously affect the
            implementation of a reform program.
